title: What will be the end-of-day closing value for the South Korean won (₩) against the U.S. dollar on 15 July 2020?
preds: Today one day before closure, it is at 1207. Trend of the last two days is increasing, therefore I am adjusting for more probability on the 1,200-1250 bracket.

For 2020, one American Dollar has equalled
   average: ₩ 1,206.360
   minimum: ₩ 1,152.700
   maximum: ₩ 1,287.820 Currently at 1200.5.  So close to both. https://fx-rate.net/USD/KRW/#graph
On the bubble, this is guessing not forecsting.
Currently over 1200.00 adjusting my forecast upward.
Won is moving in the other direction now
Yesterday's jump put it above 1200. From the current value and random walking with a daily volatility of about 0.5% now the probabilities concentrate on the 1200-1250 bucket.
Moving closer to 1,200.0000 as the market fluctuates upward.
On a knife edge six days prior, still anyone's guess if we end up above or below 1200
Trending down, currently around 1190.  Could easily go back up.  Too close to call.
Currently at 1195.0000 and on a downward trend, I have updated my forecast toward the probability that exchange will fall between 1150.0000-1200.0000.
Looking like the won is continuing to strengthen. Putting more in the second bucket.

6th July: 3 days in a row closed below 1200.00
Monthly trend is also downwards but has jumped by more than 5.00 in single day twice in last few days.

Hasn't been above 1,250.0000 in the last five years. The question is obviously (well, maybe not obviously) whether it will close above or below 1,200.0000. This is a similar question to "is the South Korean economy going back to normal?" Cases are spiking but not anomalously. Pegging this at 70% for now.
3rd july: 1198/$. Trend is downwards. Need to monitor over next 3-4 days. Might need to make big adjustment
This may be more about the dollar and less about the won. Dollar still robust but wiggling. We have two weeks to see what happens.
Won is strengthening perhaps on the perception that their economy is back on track or soon to be.
There is downward trend over last 30 days. Already closed below 1200 level. Adjusting the forecast to lower values

Still kicking right around 1200, with a couple of days under it this month [1]. The wan is currently strengthening below 1200, with today's closing at 1198. I am going to shift to favoring the lower value.  [1] https://www.xe.com/currencyconverter/convert/?Amount=1&From=USD&To=KRW
June 28th update: Exchange rate is dancing around 1200 for last 3 days. Closely watch but no need to change the forecast as of now.
Adjusting the forecast considering the downward trend over last 30 days.
Still hovering above 1200 as the dollar has strengthened this week.
The won dips into the lower bucket on strength not seen in a while. Only 3 weeks to go will this trend continue?

I feel that this is very much like a coin toss. The short-range trend during the last month is to go down, leaving it at about 1190 at 15th of July. The medium-range trend (once the epidemic was under control and removing the peak that happened around 20 of March) is a slightly growing plateau, which would suggest something in the range of 1210 by 15 of July. Not to mention the volatility, which could change the coin toss even during the last day of the question. Difficult to be more specific.
Just went below 1200. Readjusting the forecast
Won is slowly gaining strength as the dollar slowly loses strength.
Won edged lower since last forecast. Making small adjustment
Didn't South Korea lose the war and divide the country? Kim would be singing KPop if the USA didn't protect every aspect of the South's defenses.
Bouncing around 1200, could land on the bubble

Current value 1,204 28 buisness days to go. 
Base rates (over last 19 years) for decreases of at least -0.004: 44%| -0.054: 3%| 
Increases of at least 0,096: 0| 0.046:  4%
=> Base rates 3|41|52|4|0
Correction for model uncertainty: 5|39|49|6|1

In the last week the won has strengthen a tad and is hanging *right around* 1200 wan-to-dollar [1]. Moving out of the higher end bucket. [1]  https://www.xe.com/currencyconverter/convert/?Amount=1&From=USD&To=KRW
I'll sit on the fence, even though it hurts.
5 weeks to go, the won appears to be appreciating back to the rate it enjoyed prior to the pandemic.
Korea is suffering loss of exports, Bloomberg "Shipments to the U.S. declined 29% and those to EU dropped 25%." This could drive the won lower over the month.
For the past two months it has remained between more than ₩1,200.0000 but less than ₩1,250.0000. It's currently at ₩1,237.5800.
Trending to a lower value very subtly.

The 1.2 to 1.25 range feels fairly safe, as things could improve a bit for the US over that period, but it seems like South Korea is also going to be in a very solid position moving forward. With that said, I kind of want to lean more on the 1.15 to 1.2 range over 1.25 to 1.3, just because if things are more "normal" this summer then 2019 becomes more relevant and the "won" spent a lot of time in the 1.15 to 1.2 range last year.

Current value: 1.233, 43 business days to go.  
According to https://www.investing.com/currencies/usd-krw-historical-data, we had increases of over .67 on 37 of 2550 43 day windows, increases of over .17 on 821, decreases of over .33 on 474 and decreases of over 0.83 on 26.

The S Korean economy is a example for multiple countries across the world. The SK governance apparatus has also proven to be capable at handling the pandemic without crippling lockdowns. 1,250 has been a strong support for the Won, and I don't see it getting broken. So a 65% chance for Won being in the 1,200 to 1,250 range for next couple of months.
Currently hanging around 1220 won to one dollar and has been pretty stable since early March. The previous range before a short-term spike in March was between 1160 and 1180.
holy smoke it jumped to 1222 today - what a ride.
Such an exciting currency to chart., its like a quantum constant.

With South Korea effectively handling the pandemic and its recovery as seen from the exports of electronic products, it has proved strong fundamentals and therefore there will be increased demand for Won from international investors.  However, with the possibility of further waves of the pandemic, investors may look for safer bets in the form of gold, and this may affect the prospects of Won strengthening against the dollar.
Same O, Same O. sweet spot.
Using as a reference: https://fx-rate.net/USD/KRW/#graph The trend appears it will stay above 1200 and below 1250.
April 8 = 1,217.2000KRW/$  sitting in the sweet spot.
April 7 = 1,219.6500KRW/$  Still in the sweet spot.
April 6 = 1,229.4000KRW/$ steady as she goes. No one is rocking this boat.
April 3 = 1,231.4000KRW/$ are we settling in to a sweet spot. 3 months to sort it out

April 2 = 1,229.49 KRW / $ this seems to be the near term sweetspot. 
Will it continue to stregthen? Not many people buying TV's, phones, or autos right now. And there are still those DPRK missles flying around.
March 30 = 1,220.8/$ Continues to bounce between buckets 2 & 3. Korea doing a great job dealing with covid-19 yet cases still exist and still climbing albeit slowly.
March 27=1,211.0300KRW/$ slowly strengthening as they continue to contain covid-19 as a model for us all.
Korea has shown its ability to manage the pandemic

USD is getting stronger lately, likely due to the view of it being a safe haven currency. Based on this, am flattening out my prediction. However, I don't think it will remain this way through to July.
Fed policy / SK polict / Global flows - very hard to predict. Flattening out my prections.
March 23 = 1,252.75 and headed to more familiar territory.

South Korea has a good handle on covid-19, however the US's failure to contain has resulted in disturbances in the market and a retreat from US equities to the US dollar [0]. As covid-19 has been mitigated in south korea, and grows uncontrollably in the US, counter-intuitively USD has risen against KRW. KRW futures are priced at 0.0008048 at the time of writing indicating a market expected price of 1243KRW/usd in July [1] Dollar index options are indicating relatively high expected volatility in the dollars value: 10% on an annual basis. [2] Indicating a 5.6% standard deviation [3]. given normal random variable mu=1243, sd = 5.6% * 1243:
P(X<1150) = 9%
P(X>1150, X<1200) = 18%
P(X>1200, X<1250) = 27%
P(X>1250, X<1300) = 25%
P(X>1300) = 21% We apply a heuristic to adjust for fat tails[4][5]:
10%
18%
25%
25%
22% [0] https://www.marketwatch.com/story/why-the-us-dollars-relentless-rally-is-causing-pain-for-emerging-markets-2020-03-19
[1] https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/fx/emerging-market/korean-won.html
[2] https://www.barchart.com/futures/quotes/DXU20/volatility-greeks/sep-20
[3] there are 0.31 years until july 15: sqrt(0.31) * 10% = 5.6% standard deviation
[4] heuristic is (+1%, +0%, -2%, +0%, +1%) 
[5] https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/fat-tail-risk-what-it-means-and-why-you-should-be-aware-it-2015-11-02 - we know this applies here because implied volatility per [1] is greater at the tails.
I have absolutely no idea about this so fair chance across the board
The Korea brand will get a boost from its C Virus accomplishments.
March 19 = 1,255.93 dollar still insanely high requiring more won.
As the US leaders attempt to stem the flow of economic bleeding, the dollar will become less valuable.

Unless the South Korean number of cases have a major and unexpected upswing, the US economy will have a major shock within the next 3 months as the policies to try and limit US cases start to bite. Hospitality, creative and travel industries have a mountain to climb after this, and the colossal support of the government, there will be a lot of unemployment. Either way, though, I think the Won will be in a considerably stronger position than the USD by that point.
March 18 =1,245.6500KRW/ $   lowest in the last five years. Dollar benefitting as safe haven, won not so much.

On second thought, the three-month volatility (https://www.ratesfx.com/predictions/pred-krw.html)  is probably a better estimate for the volatility we will experience in the next 3-4 months as well, so I'm using that instead. Re-running my Monte Carlo simulation with the three month volatility (6.78% annualized) and the Won price at the time of writing (1,264.85) gives me my new probability spread.

I guess because of the US dollar 'safe haven' currency status, the Korean won will weaken gradually throughout the year despite the FED rate cut to zero. What would negative rates do? I have no idea. four months is still a long time to wait and find out.  https://www.ratesfx.com/predictions/pred-krw.html
https://finance.yahoo.com/news/surging-u-dollar-next-big-061231003.html
https://www.marketwatch.com/story/the-us-dollar-refuses-to-stay-down-heres-why-2020-03-17
https://in.reuters.com/article/asia-forex-emerging/em-asia-fx-most-currencies-weaken-as-pandemic-panic-boosts-dollar-appeal-idINL4N2B60RV

I know little about forex trading, so I'm going with baselines. I have no reason to expect the won will trend higher or lower than it is now. I got the yearly volatility from here https://www.ratesfx.com/predictions/pred-krw.html (though I note that the recent volatility has been higher, I'll use the yearly as my default), then wrote a little script to do a Monte Carlo simulation using that volatility and today's KRW price, which is how I got my probability spreads here. I'll be revisiting my estimate, adapting it with changes in volatility and current price, and especially if it seems the recent volatility is significantly different from the one I used in my calculations.

The won is in new territory, has not been here in the last 5 years. Stronger dollar does not help the exchange rate.
Productivity may not matter if people are not buying phones and TVs and cars. Demand not likely to recover for these items in Q2.
The won enters new territory at 1,225.82 on March 16. In the last five years its been here once. Korea has done a great job countering the virus, but the economy has taken a hit.
I think the $ is going to take a bath too.
March 13 = 1,219.41 / dollar. The covid-19 trap door is pressuring won as productivity slows and demand diminishes. We have reached a tipping point with 3 months to go.

What will be the end-of-day closing value for the South Korean won (₩) against the U.S. dollar on 15 July 2020?
March 10= 1,193.15 per dollar, near the tipping point.

The value hasn't been below 1,150 since April last year. The value hasn't been above 1,300 in the past 5 years.  Despite the virus, the value has remained strong. Potential for the virus to negatively impact the KRW value could lessen as the virus goes global. Indications that the US is struggling to handle the virus could be indicative that USD will suffer. Within a few months, any potential impact of coronavirus on these values will be clear.  The other news I'm looking out for is indications of tension between N Korea and S Korea. The most recent story I found is reports yesterday that N Korea has started making launches for the first time in months.  South Korea's Defense Ministry said that these launches violated 2018 agreements to ease military tension. With time it will become clear whether these launches are insignificant or if they reflect an uptake in tensions.  https://edition.cnn.com/2020/03/08/asia/north-korea-launch/index.html

The South Korean economy may falter in the 1st quarter with potentially negative growth, and stagnate a little in the 2nd quarter, but the currency will hold strength against the dollar with expected US federal reserve cuts in interest rates in the pipeline.

Based on Bloomberg, median rate over last 3 years is hovering just under 1150.
Since Apr 2019: 1150-1200 range. Major US events: none affecting. Democratic primary candidate to be determined arnd July.
Major KR events: possibly NK/SK conflict around memorial day.
Currency continues to strengthen, amazing in light of their crippling virus crisis. March 5= 1,181.3 to the dollar.

This is a very tricky forecast. Fundamentally the big factors are US-China trade war and spillover to korean exports; Japan-Korea trade conflict / tariffs; coronovirus impact on SK, US and China; Bank efforts both US/SK via fiscal and monetary policy... and so foreign money outflows. Given this Won has held up vs USD quite well and the crowd forecast at writing of 42% in the 1150/1200 range seems reasonable as the most likely scenario. But the weight seems more disperse. I don't see Won as that likely to go back above 1200 and hold, given the economic uncertainties.  ..... as an side,  JPM forecast. 1190 1Q20 1170 Q220 and 1175. Q320 and 1185 4Q20 - but FX is extremely hard to predicg accurately
March 4 = 1,187.7 per dollar, excellent performance in troubling times.

checked and I used wrong ratio so I correct.

Markets will fluctuate, so they say. March 3 = 1,195 per dollar. Korea is taking aggressive steps in a difficult situation.

I think we may all be over-thinking this. I'll stick with the outside view for now. Over the last ten years, the highest the won has ever been is roughly 1,470. The lowest is about 900. Almost all of that time its been between 1,000 and 1,200, and recently 1,100 to 1,200. Currently the trend us up but within the range of the last 10 years.

Assuming COVID-19 will have some lasting impact with S. Korea impacted and cases growing.
Expecting some recovery by mid-July. Hmm - are some other forecasters reading this wrong or am I ? 25% of forecasts think that Korean Won will be significantly STRONGER (less Won per Dollar) than currently and reversing the recent trend of weakening vs. $ !!

After working on setting a base rate based on historical price distribution and some monte carlo modeling, taking an average of the monte carlo output as a prior here. Nudging this prior to incorporate historical bounds on the price range. I'm not really adjusting the prior based on any of the current economic information yet. A lot could shift and I'm not sure I have a good handle on how much central bank activity etc. is not already incorporated into the current price and futures price.

Inflation is expected to decline in both South Korea and the US due to demand shocks from the coronavirus. South Korea is more dependent on China, so the effects may be more pronounced there. Fed cuts will increase the incentive to hold South Korean currency relative to the dollar. Although, South Korea may also cut rates in response to similar pressures. The US Current Account Balance is strengthening and the South Korean Current Account Balance is decreasing which will drive USD appreciation (i.e. more won per dollar). Further, continued concerns about global growth will increase demand for the USD to hold haven assets. Looking back historically, the only time since the GFC that the KRWUSD rate got close to 1,250 (1,248) was during 2016 amid concerns about a global growth slowdown. The only times it jumped above 1,300 were the 1997 Asian Financial Crisis, the dotcom bubble, and the GFC. I'm discounting the probability of similar financial disasters happening before July 15.  I think the Current Account trends described above are already priced in to a degree, but could push the rate higher (though not above 1,250). History also suggests the exchange rate is much more likely to stay below 1,150 than above 1,250. Base case is for coronavirus trends to persist in the near-term, but be replaced by macro variables longer term.
Linear interpolation of algorithmic forecasts for end of June and end of July based on monthly data. Expect to update monthly until closing date is near.

- currently circa 1usd = 1,200 won
- given current economic situation + covid -> USD strengthen vis a vis won/won weaken vis a vis USD higher probability than the won strengthen/usd weaken 
- USD also seen as safe haven asset

What will be the end-of-day closing value for the South Korean won (₩) against the U.S. dollar on 15 July 2020?
Feb 28 rate is 1214.7  Range for the year 1124. to 1222.8. Currency likely to weaken as production stalls. Weaker currency would stimulate demand somewhat and help restore economy. Nadir likely in July.
